title: Thursday, 17th October 2019

d over Labour, with the average of the last 5 polls showing they are now 9.7% ahead, up from 8.9% last week. This is after applying our adjustment for “house” effects, i.e. variations arising due to different polling company methodologies.
 Brexit Party support continues to trend lower, while the Liberal Democrats have also seen a reversal of their postparty conference polling bounce. We also update our models with fresh regional polling data for Scotland and Wales. SNP now projected to get 48 seats, down from 50.

 A uniform swing model based on the current polls and the 2017 general election gives the Conservatives 339 seats with an effective outright majority of 34. Even though the margin for victory is slim, our sensitivity analysis indicates that the Tory’s would still (just about) gain a majority if their polling support was 3%-pts lower.

BE11:32am

Revenues tracking slightly ahead of our expectations. Following an excellent start to the year, with solid performances from Insurance and Money boosted by an exceptional performance in Energy, management, at the interim results, set a more cautious tone for the second half; anticipating more challenging comparatives in Money and Energy, along with the anticipated impact of the August reduction in the Energy price cap. While this has played out in the Money category (Q319 -5%, YTD +1%), Insurance remained solid (Q319 +3%) and Energy continues to outperform (Q3+20%, YTD +40%) supported by good product offers. Overall revenue growth in Q3 was 4%, ahead of our forecast of 1% for the quarter.

farrago @rw42 I'd support moving ML behind the paywall too
BE11:33am

Marketing margins may come under pressure following algorithm changes. Within the insurance category (55% revenues), MONY has flagged some volatility in the natural search rankings following an update to Google's algorithm at the end of Q2. This signals some compression in the marketing margin as the group works to rebuild its ranking during H2.

And Stifel.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Mixed signals in terms of premium inflation: After 7 quarters of year on year decreases, there are a number of signals that set the stage towards a gentle firming of car insurance premiums.

(1) Recent updates from insurance groups point to upward rate pressure. For example, Sabre in its recent results call highlight industry wide claims inflation, the potential for reinsurance price increases following recent revisions to the Ogden discount rate, and, changes in claims management company behaviour in anticipation of personal injury legal reforms.
(2) The Confused.com Car Insurance Price Index (released 11 October), shows that after 7 quarters of declines, average car insurance premiums edged up year on year over the last two quarters: Q219 +3% and Q319 +5%. It also points to the fact that fewer customers renewed with the same insurer during Q319 (38% vs 52% in Q219).

BE11:38am

3) In its 4th October interim report into the pricing of home and motor insurance the FCA asserts that 6m home ad motor insurance customers in the UK do not get a good deal, wasting £1.2bn a year on insurance. This kind of media attention plays very well for the PCWs. Although, we note, one of the policies under consideration risks encouraging customer complacency rather action; it is considering banning or restricting practices 'like raising prices for consumers who renew year on year or automatically moving customers onto cheaper equivalent deals'.

Despite these signals, MONY remain relatively cautious indicating a fairly flat premium environment. In Q4, management expects a similar trading dynamic, with a weakening performance from Money, leaving it on track to deliver to consensus.

Reiterate Buy rating. Despite being at a low point it he product cycle we forecast 7-8% earnings growth this year and next; a hardening of insurance premiums could present upside to this. Together with the potential associated with the B2B and Mortgage growth initiatives (up to 160p of value), and the possibility for further cash returns from next year, we view the FY19e 14.5x EV/EBITDA and 20.9x PE as unchallenging. MONY trades at a slight discount to GOCO (FY19 EV/EBITDA of 15.5x, 22.8x PE) although GOCO is absorbing start up losses from its auto-switching initiatives.

Bluesky21 I think the question with UK motor insurance is how much do you worry about regulations
nichoman if im at my desk - which i usually am - ML brings me to the FT website every day at 11am. very few websites offer anything that commands my loyalty in the same way.
BE11:39am

And Peel Hunt.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Moneysupermarket saw continued strong performance in Home Services in Q3, while Money underperformed. Insurance is still affected by the difficult premium environment. Overall the company saw revenues grow for the quarter by 4%. While the board is confident in meeting full year expectations, they have flagged that the Money segment is expected to weaken for the remainder of the year. We expect the shares to drift today, after such a strong run YTD (up c40%). We maintain our Hold recommendation and target price of 350p.

BE11:39am

he mix of performance for Money and Home Services came as a surprise today. We expected Money to have been more robust while growth for Home Services to be slower after a very strong performance in H1. However, this has not been the case. The company has flagged that the Money segment is expected to weaken for the remainder of the year. The stock has been strong YTD, up c40%, therefore we expect the shares to drift slightly with today’s outlook.

BE11:40am

And Shore.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

We are encouraged by the portfolio effect evident in this morning’s update which demonstrates the benefits of the group’s diverse product offering. More broadly, we regard Moneysupermarket.com as a well-managed business that is well-placed to capitalise on our expectation of a positive medium-term outlook for switching activity across a range of products and services. We would particularly cite: strong brand awareness; the breadth of its inventory and; the substantial investment that it has made in technology and mobile functionality as important factors in this regard.

Based on our current forecasts, we anticipate three-year aggregate EPS and DPS growth of 26% and 21%, respectively accompanied by strong cash generation (ave. conversion 114%) which in our view seems fully reflected in the group’s current stock valuation (FY19F and FY20F P/E and underlying DY ratios of 21.7x and 2.9% and 20.0x and 3.1%, respectively). Specifically, we see c.8% upside to our fair value estimate of 429p (derived from a combination of peer group growth comparison and DCF approaches) which means that its stock remains in HOLD territory for now.

A weak quarter, in our view, especially on volumes as the three big markets US, India and China still remain challenging. We would look out for any detail on the CEO’s statement in the 3Q release which says, “we will step-up competitive top line performance through innovation and portfolio evolution to serve the faster growing geographies and channels”. This is particularly interesting given that the messaging from the company on M&A seems to be changing where it has said that the risk of value destruction on small deals is increasing and it’s considering bigger deals where it sees more value.

Performance by division

By region, OSG in Asia/AMET/RUB was 5.6%, Americas 1.5% and Europe down -0.3%. Emerging markets 5.1% and Developed markets down -0.1%.

By category: OSG in Beauty & Personal Care was 2.8%, Home Care 5.4% and Food & Refreshments 1.7%

The main Q3 headwinds were:

· Weak market growth with India and China while LatAm remains difficult

· Ice Cream volumes down (unfavourable weather)

· Hair care competitive intensity remains high and the business is declining in the US (losing share to P&G)

· Exceptional Q2 Home Care growth normalised in Q3

There were also some positives:

· Dressings business returned to growth in Q3 (vs. share loss to Kraft Heinz in the US in Q2)

· South East Asia strong, driven mainly by Indonesia and Vietnam

Bluesky21 Actually, even for supposed all-weather performers like L'Oréal, W Europe and N America have been anaemic
BE11:47am

11:46 am
BE11:47am

By region, Europe marginally improved sequentially, whilst Asia/AMET/RUB and the Americas both decelerated and offset this improvement. As a result EM growth decelerated to 5.1% (vs. +7.4% in 2Q19), while DM growth started to stabilise at -0.1% in 3Q (vs. -1.6% in 2Q). The deterioration in EMs was largely related to Latin America in 3Q which benefited in 2Q from the lapping of the truckers strike. Within North America growth was positive (vs. flat in 2Q) helped by price growth, but the company continued to see challenges in the hair care portfolio (which is consistent with the Nielsen data we track).
By division the Food & Refreshment business accelerated, driven by better price growth and a volume recovery in part related to ice cream sales. The BPC and Home Care divisions both decelerated driven by reduced pricing in both divisions, as the company lapped sizeable price increases from the prior year (3Q18 pricing accelerated).

Bluesky21 The degree to which EM growth matters to consumer companies has got less coverage lately, probably because people are taking Chinese/Indian growth for granted
BE11:47am

We do not expect material changes to consensus expectations, which are towards the bottom end of the FY guidance range, following broadly in line growth for 3Q. Consensus currently expects FY19 organic growth to come in at 3.4%, which implied organic sales growth of 3.6% for 4Q to be delivered (an acceleration from the current 2.9% level but on a comp that is 100bps easier).
We note that Unilever shares have underperformed the European Staples sector, up 14% vs sector up 29% YTD.

Overall, Unilever’s conference call provided few incrementals post an inline
Q319, while we remain concerned about the growth momentum
heading into FY20. To us, the deceleration in pricing in HC and in BPC
should be a cause for concern as these are the historical drivers of
Unilever’s top line. In a marketplace growing at c3%, we remain cautious
on top line and see expectations of a pickup in FY20 as overly optimistic
in the face of Q319 delivery. Despite today’s share price relief, we
continue to see risks to expectations on top line and EPS growth and
remain UW. Key highlights: 1) F&R improved thanks to return to growth
in US dressings and US ice cream, 2) US hair remains challenging given
P&G recovery, 3) India and China slowing, 4) cautiously optimistic on
Brazil (up 1% in Q319), 5) unconvincing on drivers of re-acceleration in
BPC, and 6) Europe and the USA muted.

BE11:59am

[T]he backward looking stuff, whilst impressive, is completely overshadowed by two pieces of news from the USA. Firstly WH Smith has won a contract with an as yet unnamed airport on the eastern seaboard for two WH Smith stores and one In Motion. This is very good news and a fillip that the shares have been waiting for. In normal circumstances we would have expected further airport contract wins to follow in time. However, these are not normal circumstances given that WH Smith has made a major acquisition in the US travel arena and its potential is multiplied. It is paying $400m for Marshalls Retail group (MRG), which has 170 stores in North America. 59 of these stores are within airports (they have $84m of sales) and another 33 of these outlets are contracted to open before the end of 2024. The other 111 stores are in resorts and tourist locations (predominantly Las Vegas): they have a turnover of about $120m. MRG EBITDA last year was $31m. This is a completely transformative deal for WH Smith, and propels it into the big league of global travel businesses. We would imagine that WH Smith is more interested in accelerating the airport opening programme and it is clear that its US business will be well in excess of 250 stores (including InMotion) in a couple of years’ time. The sum paid is not a low one: on historics the multiple is nearly 14x EBITDA and 2x sales. But such a business was never going to come cheap and there will be synergies available, such that it looks like a 10ish x multiple. That’s a similar price to InMotion. The $400m will be found via debt and an equity placing. We won’t change our numbers to reflect this deal just yet but it does appear to be nicely enhancing.

BE12:06pm

Morgan Stanley:

BE12:06pm

Prime Minister Johnson and EU Commission President Juncker have announced agreement on a revised Brexit deal. But we assume the DUP remains opposed, and still think the deal will not pass parliament, leading to an extension and elections. With DUP support, we think the chance of this parliament approving the deal would rise from the current 30% to 60%. Done deal? The revised Brexit deal would leave Northern Ireland (NI) legally out of the EU customs regime, but with a customs border administered in the Irish Sea. There would additionally be a consent mechanism, allowing the NI Assembly the opportunity after four years to decide to leave the new arrangements. The DUP says...? In its latest official statement this morning, the DUP announced that it was not able to support the new arrangements, and we remain sceptical that it has changed its position. In short, we see the DUP as opposing the proposed NI regime, and therefore think the deal will likely not pass parliament. Prime Minister Johnson may have agreed to a deal without DUP support, as reverting to a no-deal policy would likely result in division in the Conservative party. If the government loses the vote on the deal at the special session on Saturday, we see an extension and elections to decide the way forward, with Prime Minister Johnson campaigning on his current deal. With Labour campaigning on a second referendum between a soft Brexit and remain, the realistic spectrum of outcomes is from Prime Minister Johnson’s deal to remain – i.e., no-deal becomes a tail risk. Hence, we remain constructive on the Brexit outcome. If the DUP was to confirm that it is on board with the agreed deal, we would attach a 60% probability to this parliament agreeing the deal, with ratification by Christmas a realistic prospect.
